tasks: Review Tesler's Law (https://lawsofux.com/teslers-law/) and create a simple diagram illustrating how it applies to your current design process. (Score improvement: +3% in UX Fundamentals)

Identify 2 areas where you can apply Hick’s Law (https://lawsofux.com/hicks-law/) in your existing projects. Write down specific examples and potential solutions. (Score improvement: +2% in UX Fundamentals)

Familiarize yourself with the 8-point grid system for layout design. Create a simple wireframe using this system to improve your navigation skills. (Score improvement: +1% in UI Craft & Visual Design)

Apply Aesthetic-Usability Effect (https://lawsofux.com/aesthetic-usability-effect/) to redesign a simple product page, focusing on color schemes and typography. (Score improvement: +4% in UX Fundamentals)

Conduct a user interview using the Jobs-to-be-Done framework to identify pain points in your current design process. Document 3 key findings and potential solutions. (Score improvement: +5% in User Research & Validation)

Create a simple usability test plan for a hypothetical product feature, including heuristics from the NNGroup's 10 Usability Heuristics (https://www.nngroup.com/articles/ten-usability-heuristics/). (Score improvement: +2% in UX Fundamentals)

Develop a basic product strategy document using the Laws of UX as a foundation. Focus on one key aspect, such as user research or design principles. (Score improvement: +6% in Product Thinking & Strategy)

Create a simple wireframe for a hypothetical feature, applying the 8-point grid system and considering Hick’s Law. Document your thought process and design decisions. (Score improvement: +3% in UI Craft & Visual Design)
Conduct a usability test of your own design work using the NNGroup's 10 Usability Heuristics. Identify areas for improvement and document your findings. (Score improvement: +4% in UX Fundamentals)

Develop a comprehensive product strategy document, incorporating all key aspects of the Laws of UX. Focus on one key aspect, such as user research or design principles. (Score improvement: +10% in Product Thinking & Strategy)
Create a simple prototype for a hypothetical feature using your new skills and knowledge. Document your thought process and design decisions. (Score improvement: +5% in UI Craft & Visual Design)

Conduct an in-depth user interview using the Jobs-to-be-Done framework to identify pain points in your current design process. Document 5 key findings and potential solutions, including a clear plan for implementation. (Score improvement: +8% in User Research & Validation)

resources.readup: As an Explorer UX designer, you have the unique opportunity to shape the user experience of innovative products and services. By leveraging your skills in UX Fundamentals, UI Craft & Visual Design, User Research & Validation, Product Thinking & Strategy, and Collaboration & Communication, you can help create seamless and intuitive interactions that leave a lasting impact on users.

resources.title: 10 Usability Heuristics for User Interface Design
resources.description: 7 10 Usability Heuristics for User Interface Design ================================================= Jakob Nielsen ![](https://media.nngroup.com/medi...

topics.name: Understanding Hick’s Law and its Application in UX Design
topics.summary: Applying Hick's Law to design interfaces that minimize decision fatigue and maximize user efficiency.
practice_points: Analyze 3 existing websites for Hick's Law violations and propose redesigns to improve usability
Create a heuristic evaluation checklist using Hick’s Law as a starting point

topics.name: Conducting User Research with the Jobs-to-be-Done Framework
topics.summary: Using the Jobs-to-be-Done framework to uncover user motivations and pain points in a real-world context.
practice_points: Conduct 2 interviews using the Jobs-to-be-Done framework with users from different demographics

topics.name: Aesthetic-Usability Effect: Designing for Visual Hierarchy
topics.summary: Applying the Aesthetic-Usability Effect to create visually appealing and intuitive interfaces.
practice_points: Design 3 wireframes with varying levels of visual hierarchy using color, typography, and spacing
